abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Finance and
            Social Sector Development Policy Loan (DPL) Project for
            Dominican Republic were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was substantial,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the global economic crisis exacted a heavy
            toll on the Dominican economy, endangering macroeconomic
            balances and in particular the Government's fiscal
            position. The DPL proved to be a timely, flexible and
            effective instrument that helped the Government meets the
            challenges of the global crisis within a sustainable fiscal
            strategy that protected social sectors. Past crises led to
            sharp increases in poverty; to avoid this risk, Bank support
            helped the Government prioritize spending, provide basic
            services, and meet its payment obligations, and at the same
            time restoring confidence and macroeconomic sustainability.
            Moreover, by offering policy support for the
            Government's reform agenda during a period of
            vulnerability, the Bank was able to help articulate and
            contribute positively to pro-poor, pro-development and
            institutional strengthening policies that may have otherwise
            suffered backtracking during a prolonged economic crisis.
            DPL support also provided a window of opportunity for
            achieving a fundamental reform of the subsidies regime. The
            politically popular electricity subsidies under PRA
            (Programa de Reduccion de Apagones - Program to Reduce
            Blackouts) and the universal subsidy on liquefied gas were
            costly transfers that the Government struggled to address in
            the past. The crisis environment and DPL policy support
            facilitated their replacement with targeted subsidies
            BONOLUZ (cash transfer subsidy of electricity consumption)
            and BONOGAS (cash transfer subsidy of liquefied gas),
            generating important fiscal savings and reducing incentives
            of excess consumption. As seen in other Bank lending,
            policies that have the biggest impact are those closely
            aligned with the Government's priorities. As political
            pressures emerge, Governments are less likely to implement
            reforms if their own commitment is weak. One way to address
            potential backtracking is to structure Bank support in
            response to results achieved on the ground, in contrast to
            the current reliance on prior actions which may be only
            nominally indicative of Government commitment such as legal
            decrees or short-lived measures. The Bank's long
            history of involvement in the Dominican energy sector raises
            questions regarding the prospects for successful electricity
            reform given the political climate in the Dominican Republic.
